title: Baptism of Ixtlilxochitl II
creator: Vivar y Valderrama, JosŽ
description: Ixtlilxochitl II (c. 1500-1550) was the son of Nezahualpilli, Tlatoani of Texcoco. In 1516 Nezahualpilli died, and the succession was contested by several of his sons, including Cacamatzin and Ixtlilxochitl. The former gained the support of Moctezuma II, Tlatoani of the Aztec Empire. A civil war ensued, and ended in a tripartite division of Tetzcoco, by which one third of the kingdom, with the capital, was awarded to Cacamatzin, the northern part to his brother Ixtlilxochitl, and the third part to another claimant to the throne. Ixtlilxochitl became from that time the enemy of Moctezuma II.
subject: Contact, Conquest, and Conversion: Mission Architecture and Decoration in Colonial Latin America

title: Historia de Tlaxcala: The Erection of the First Cross
creator: Camargo, Diego Mu–oz
description: Pen and ink. This MS. belonged to the Royal Library of Philip II., to whom it was  presented by the author whose autograph signature it bears, at the close of his epistle dedicatory (2, 6 verso) and it was there in 1629 when Antonius Leonius (De Leon Pinelo) published at Madrid his Bibliotheca Indica Occidentalis.
subject: Contact, Conquest, and Conversion: Mission Architecture and Decoration in Colonial Latin America
location: University of Glasgow, Archives and Special Collections
rights: "Historia de Tlaxcala", University of Glasgow, Archives and Special Collections, (http://collections.gla.ac.uk/#/details/ecatalogue/296613)

title: Mural painting, Black panther Otomi warrior vanquishing Chichimec foe
description: Mural painting from the church of San Miguel Arcangel de Ixmiquilpan. The tlacuilos have adorned the church with an allegory of their defense of Christianity against a real contemporary foe. An abstract battle between good and evil is recast in the guise of the longstanding conflict between civilized and Christian Otomi and barbaric pagan Chichimec, underscoring the benefits of living in a Christian and Spanish state. This reading is supported by connections btw the churchÕs titular saint, St Michael the Archangel, and the pre-Columbian deity Tezcatlipoca, the Aztec patron of warriors.
subject: Contact, Conquest, and Conversion: Mission Architecture and Decoration in Colonial Latin America

title: Mass of St. Gregory
creator: Anonymous
description: Feather work/amantecayotl, 68 x 5 x 2.3 cm. Made for Pope Paul III in Mexico by the feather artists at San Jose de los Naturales (the students of de Gante), commissioned by the Nahua noble Diego de Alvarado Huanitzin (1st colonial governor of Tenochtitlan; the nephew and son in law of Moctezuma II) as a gift for Pope Paul III.
subject: From the Codex to Mestizo Baroque: Hybrid Genres of Painting in Colonial Latin America
source: Artstor; Data From: University of California, San Diego.

title: Christ Child Wearing the Imperial Inca Crown and Catholic Priestly Robes
creator: Anonymous
description: Oil and Gold leaf on canvas. Another portrait of a statue, and the only painting of its kind in existence. His attire is a transcultural hybrid: He wears the cape and gilded tunic of a Bishop, with a white linen alb visible beneath. But he also sports a mascaypacha (red forehead fringe that was prerogative of an Inca ruler), and he wears sandals with puma heads. Also has an elaborate neo-Inca headpiece decorated with pre-Hispanic heraldic emblems. It bears kantutas (the Inca sacred flowers). It has a black and white feather from the corequenque (the mythical falcon used by Inca royalty as a dynastic symbol). These are juxtaposed with circular ramparts, scepters, and a rainbow (all refs to the Inca fortress above Cuzco called Sacsayhuaman). And, the flowers in the vases on either side of the figure include roses, dahlias, and white lilies. Lily is a symbol for the purity of Mary, but the lilies that appear here are the amancay, a native Peruvian lily.
subject: From the Codex to Mestizo Baroque: Hybrid Genres of Painting in Colonial Latin America

subject: From the Codex to Mestizo Baroque: Hybrid Genres of Painting in Colonial Latin America
